text: PD Awareness month is April, but you can learn about PD all year long.
Parkinson's Disease is incurable. But it is treatable.
Parkinson's Disease itself is not fatal. It can, however, increase the risk of things like falling and aspiration pneumonia.
An estimated 10 million people are living with Parkinson's Disease worldwide.
Parkinson's Diseases affects 50% more men than women.
The average age to receive a diagnosis of Parkinson's Disease is 60 years old.
Children can be diagnosed with Parkinson's Disease. A diagnosis before the age of 50 is called Young Onset Parkinson's Disease (YOPD).
Researchers have identified several genetic markers that indicate increased risk of a Parkinson's Disease diagnosis.
Environmental toxins including metals, pesticides, and herbicides may trigger the onset of Parkinson's Disease.
Parkinson's Disease destroys cells that produce dopamine. This interferes with the communication pathways between cells.
Lewy bodies are clumps of malformed alpha synuclein (protein) molecules that may trigger cellular death in Parkinson's Disease.
The diagnosis of Parkinson's Disease is clinical and addresses symptoms like tremor, loss of balance, and rigidity.
A DaTScan is a procedure to help diagnose Parkinson's Disease. It involves a radioactive tracer to help image dopamine levels in the brain.

links.name: What role does a DaTScan play in Parkinson's Disease?

text: Some humans and animals are able to smell Parkinson's Disease in humans well before visible symptoms have emerged.
There are five stages of Parkinson's Disease.

links.name: Understanding the five stages of Parkinson's Disease

text: In Stage 1 of Parkinson's Disease, symptoms are typically mild and only present on one side (unilateral).
In stage 2 of Parkinson's Disease, symptoms may still be mild but occur on both sides of the body (bilateral).
In Stage 3 of Parkinson's Disease, symptoms are moderate and may result in loss of balance and slowness of movement.
In Stage 4 of Parkinson's Diseases, symptoms are severe and result in incapacitation. The patient can no longer live independently and requires assistance.
In Stage 5, the final stage of Parkinson's Disease, symptoms increase in severity and may result in falling, freezing of movements, and hallucinations/delusions.
The MDS-Unified Parkinson's Disease Rating Scale (MDS-UDPR) is used to track the progression of Parkinson's Disease.
Motor (movement) symptoms of Parkinson's Disease include stiffness, slowness, and resting tremor.
Non-motor symptoms of Parkinson's Disease include constipation, low blood pressure, excessive sweating, incontinence and sexual problems.
Mental symptoms of Parkinson's Disease include apathy, cognitive problems, mood disturbances, and psychosis.
Other symptoms of Parkinson's Disease include drooling, pain, fatigue, loss of smell, speech problems, vision changes, and difficulty swallowing.
Dopamine agonists like Ropinirole help treat symptoms of Parkinson's Disease by activating dopamine receptors to increase dopamine uptake.
The most popular (common) treatment for Parkinson's Disease is medications like Carbidopa-Levodopa that directly deliver dopamine.
Studies show that diets high in fiber, fresh organic fruits and vegetables and healthy fats like fish oil improve quality of life for people who have Parkinson's Disease.
Regular, intense exercise has been shown to slow the progression of Parkinson's Disease and help alleviate motor symptoms.

text: The Young Onset Parkinson's Network (YOPN) is a non-profit resource and community for people diagnosed with Young Onset Parkinson's Disease (YOPD).
My name is Jeremy Likness. I was diagnosed with Young Onset Parkinson's Disease in 2020 at the age of 45. The last 29 days you learned about will be the rest of my life. Thank you for listening.
